content: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), also known as drones, are powered aerial vehicles that do not carry a human operator. They can fly autonomously or be piloted remotely, and can carry a lethal or nonlethal payload. UAVs are either single air vehicles with surveillance sensors or part of a UAV system (UAS) consisting of multiple air vehicles, a ground control station, and support equipment. The military has used UAVs in recent conflicts such as Iraq and Afghanistan. UAVs, whether single air vehicles or part of a UAV system, have been used in recent military conflicts like Iraq, Afghanistan, and Kosovo. They offer advantages over manned aircraft such as eliminating pilot risk and having capabilities not limited by humans. UAVs are cost-effective and can perform "3-D" missions that are dull, dirty, or dangerous.
